captions.text: Scan-duh-nay-vee-ah!

Look at this Arctic wonderland -- fjords,
saunas, fjords, lutefisk, blondes, vikings,

blond vikings?, fjords, Ikea, babies in government
issued boxes, Santa, death metal, and fjords.

But like, where exactly are the borders of
Scandinavia -- because not off of this stuff

is in it. Scandinavia is just three countries
exactly: Sweden, Norway and Denmark. Three

kingdoms to be more precise, all of which
are on the Scandinavian peninsula -- well,

except Denmark, and errrr plus Finland. Wait,
this doesn't help at all. Forget that.

The three countries on this peninsula can
be collectively called Fennoscandia -- but

if you do everyone will look at you weird
because no one except the nerdiest of geography
nerds uses that word.
*Fennoscandia*.

So, Scandinavia is a term that's one part
geography, one part history, and one part

linguistics -- which is why people will argue
about who exactly is included. Finland is

normally excluded because she used to be considered
one of the Baltic sisters with historical

ties to mother Russia. And Denmark, though
on the other side of the sea is included because

of her relationship 'it's complicated' with
Sweden. They've had something like 15 to 21

wars between them depending on how you want
to count it. And it's complicated-er because

they mostly fought over Norway. And who wouldn't?
She beautiful -- and rich.

Anyway, when outsiders say Scandinavia they
probably mean The Nordic Countries. That's
these three *plus* Finland *and* Iceland.

Though you can hardly blame people for confusion
when organizations like the American Scandinavia

Foundation lists everyone as members. And
all the Nordic Countries sometimes advertise

abroad under the banner of Scandinavia anyway.
This is the 'Holland' approach to international

relations: if there is a fun name that everyone
likes and keeps using wrongly, just go with
it.

The Nordic countries get along well enough
that they've made an official union: The Nordic

Council, a Viking cool kids club, that other
Northern European places occasionally unrealistically

dream of joining. Though the Baltic sisters
do get to sit with them, but not actually
vote on anything.

The Nordic Council is largely a collection
of committees that tries to get its members

to cooperate on common problems like the Arctic
environment and social welfare, and business

in the region. And also finds time to make
a surprisingly long and hilariously specific

list rules for how their logo can be used.
Including a 'respect distance' the sovereignty

of which must not be violated. But the biggest
deal of the Nordic Council is that citizens

of these five countries get to live and work
in any of the others.

(Which, if you've seen the EU video -- adds
yet another semi-overlapping bubble of complexity
to an already complex region)

The immigration rule, however, doesn't apply
to Icelandic horses which are
1. Super adorables

And 2. Banished from returning to Iceland
should they ever leave. But that's a story
for another time.

Now, it wouldn't be a political union in Europe
without some special territorial weirdness
to mention, mainly:

- Aland: an autonomous region of Finland,
that speaks Swedish.

- And The Faeroe Islands and Greenland, both
countries in the Kingdom of Denmark.

Greenland is really the odd girl out in the
Nordic club, given that she's in the wrong

hemisphere and that Greenlanders aren't historically
or linguistically related to Nords. Also,

her flag ruins the otherwise consistent design
motif. But she's part of Denmark because Vikings.

Lastly there's Svalbard, an unincorporated
territory of Norway, that must be mentioned

because it has prepared for the apocalypse
with a seed bank of every plant to rebuild

all of agriculture should it be necessary.
And it's also guarded by armored bears.

So that's that -- next time you say Scandinavia,
and you're not 100% sure who that includes,
just say the The Nordic Countries instead.

Hello Internet, this is my first sponsored
video and that sponsor *is* Squarespace. Squarespace

is the easiest way to create a beautiful website,
blog, or online store for you and your ideas.

I'm very happy to have them as a sponsor because
I personally use Squarespace to run cgpgrey.com

and also hellointernet.com, the podcast I
do with Brady. If you are looking to have

your own website for just about anything,
I personally recommend Squarespace. And if

you click on the link or use the offer code
"Grey," you get 10% off at check-out. So if

you have ever considered starting your own
website, click on the link, go to Squarespace,

give them a try. It helps Squarespace, and
it helps this channel. Squarespace, build
it beautiful.

Oh how will I spend all my money? Teslas for
everyone!

comments.author: Emma Wendt

comments.text:
Hi! I just want to point out the fact that Finland is traditionally 
included in "Scandinavia" not because of some misunderstanding, but because 
for most of its history, it WAS a part of Sweden. Finland was an integral 
part of Sweden from 1249-1809 and was Russian (and thus related to it's 
"Baltic Sisters") for little over a century. And the complicated 
relationship between Denmark & Sweden was even more complicated - we shared 
kings for more than one occasion, thus being united, then breaking up 
(sometimes as Sweden, sometimes as Denmark, sometimes as Denmark-Sweden).﻿
comments.author: Johnny Olsson

comments.text:
Hi! I just want to point out the fact that Finland is traditionally 
included in "Scandinavia" not because of some misunderstanding, but because 
for most of its history, it WAS a part of Sweden. Finland was an integral 
part of Sweden from 1249-1809 and was Russian (and thus related to it's 
"Baltic Sisters") for little over a century. And the complicated 
relationship between Denmark & Sweden was even more complicated - we shared 
kings for more than one occasion, thus being united, then breaking up 
(sometimes as Sweden, sometimes as Denmark, sometimes as Denmark-Sweden).﻿

comments.author: RushSch

comments.text:
+RunawayShadow Skriftspråket under unionen med Danmark var i hovedsak 
latin. Det var presteskapet som utgjorde hovedtyngden av de som kunne lese 
og skrive, og de skrev på latin. Den første presise danske oversettelsen av 
bibelen kom først på 1600-tallet, og det tok et halvt århundre og en 
revisjon før den ble offisiellt brukt av kirken. Men uansett så kan vi jo 
se litt nærmere på det argumentet som du la frem: 


"Hadde det ikke vært for at Danmark tok over Norge i 400 år(?), så hadde vi 
nordmenn fremdeles snakket slik vikingene gjorde i vikingtiden"


Da ser du vel problemet. Både svenske og danske vikinger snakket "slik som 
vikingene gjorde i vikingtiden". Hvis norsk ikke skulle ha utviklet seg 
siden vikingtiden så lenge danskene ikke påvirket språket, da skulle vel 
ikke svensk eller dansk ha utviklet seg siden vikingtiden heller? Det kan 
hende det norske språket har blitt påvirket av dansk, men om det ikke hadde 
vert det, så ville det fremdeles ikke lignet på det språket som ble snakket 
i vikingtiden.
comments.author: TemperaMagenta

comments.text:
+TemperaMagenta Påvirket ja, selvfølgelig, men kanskje ikke i like stor 
grad om det ikke hadde vært for Kalmarunionen og deretter unionen med 
Danmark.Dansk ble tross alt brukt i Bibelen, kirka, 
konfirmasjonsundervisningen og i skolen. Det ble også en dansk-norsk

comments.author: RushSch

comments.text:
+RunawayShadow Det tviler jeg sterkt på. Det var de ferreste som kunne lese 
og skrive gjennom unionen med Danmark, så fordanskingen av Nordmenn skjedde 
stort sett bare i de øverste klassene. Størstedelen av befolkningen holdt 
på sin lokale dialekt. Norsk som språk har utviklet seg på lik linje med de 
andre kontinentale skandinaviske språkene. Norsk og svensk har for eksempel 
utviklet tonem siden vikingtiden, noe som vi ihvertfall ikke har fått av 
danskene. Utenom dette drev Norge med mye handel, og i byer som Bergen var 
nesten halvparten av befolkningen utenlandske handelsmenn. Norge er ikke i 
nærheten av å være så isolert som Island, så det norske språket ville 
fremdeles ha blitt påvirket av andre europeiske språk om vi ikke hadde vert 
i union med Danmark.
comments.author: TemperaMagenta

comments.text:
Just to make things a bit more complicated I can say that your definition 
of the Scandivanian peninsula is wrong. It does does not include the whole 
of Finland, as the peninsula you get if you draw a line from the Gulf of 
Finland (the one that goes south of Finland and ends in St Petersburg) and 
up to the White Sea, is called the Fennoscandian peninsula. The 
Scandinavian peninsula is what you get if you draw a line from the Gulf of 
Bothnia (the one between Sweden and Finland) and up to the north-eastern 
end of Norway (where it borders to Russia). So it's a smaller peninsula on 
the bigger Fennoscandian peninsula, and includes only Norway, Sweden and 
the north-western part of Finland.﻿

comments.author: Trulsbk

comments.text:
Greenland and the Faroe Islands is not part of Denmark because of vikings, 
but because of the Kiel Treaty of 1814. 
Before that they were part of the Kingdom of Norway(because of vikings) who 
were forced into a personal union with the Kingdom of Denmark after the 
Kalmar Union ended, because the Norwegian royal family, and line to the 
throne died out following the Black Death, together with about half of the 
norwegian population. "Denmark-Norway" lasted from 1524 to 1814, and was 
split up following the Napoleonic wars. 
The treaty put an end to "Denmark-Norway" but specifically excluded the 
Norwegian dependencies of Greenland, Iceland and the Faroe Islands and 
ceded them from the Norwegian crown, to remained in the union with Denmark. 
This was done without a single Norwegian representative having a say in any 
of the negotiations.﻿

comments.text:
I enjoyed this video. However, there was one (big) error. The Scandinvian 
Peninsula is not the same as Fennoscandia. The Scandinavian Peninsula is 
comprised of Sweden, Norway and only northern Finland whereas Fennoscandia 
consists of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Karelia and the Kola Peninsula, the 
latter two being part of Russia.﻿
